page.title: 17THE QUEEN ELIZABETH HOSPITAL
page.content: It is believed that there was a hospital on the Sheriff Hill site in medieval times but nothing remains of this early building. Many years ago it was the Sheriff Hill Infectious Diseases Hospital. Visitors had to stand outside and look in the window. In 1948 the hospital was opened by the Queen Mother. The outpatients department was added in 1967 by Robert Howard McKenzie Stewart Esq. M.D. Further extensions have opened over the years, the latest is due to open in January 1986. The hospital is serviced by ambulances from Gateshead, Blaydon, Washinton, Hebburn and Newcastle. It has 4 Operating Theatres and 295 beds, 3 of which are private.A new extension will add 200 new beds. A Laser for Cancer was bought by public fund raising events.
